message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only "tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells" suggests lactose intolerance. This finding is associated with an increased number of goblet cells, which produce more mucus to protect the gut from undigested lactose. The other options are suggestive of other conditions, such as celiac disease (partial villous atrophy) and Whipple disease (foamy macrophages).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells suggest lactase deficiency, indicating lactose intolerance. Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates suggests celiac disease, periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages suggest Whipple disease, and noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates suggest Crohn disease.

Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates suggest celiac disease. Periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages suggest Whipple disease. Noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates suggest Crohn disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, and among the options, only tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells are associated with lactase deficiency, which is the main cause of lactose intolerance. Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates suggests celiac disease, periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages suggest Whipple’s disease, and noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates suggest Crohn’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, and among the options, only tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells are associated with lactose intolerance. Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates is characteristic of celiac disease. Periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages are associated with Whipple disease. Noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates are seen in conditions such as sarcoidosis and Crohn disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with lactose intolerance, which is caused by the inability to digest lactose. The finding that would most strongly support the diagnosis is tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells. This is indicative of increased mucus production, which can occur as a result of lactose intolerance. The other options are associated with different conditions: partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates is associated with celiac disease, periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages are associated with Whipple's disease, and noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates are associated with sarcoidosis.

Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates suggest celiac disease, periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages suggest Whipple disease, and noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates suggest Crohn disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, and the finding that would most strongly support this diagnosis is tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells, which is consistent with lactase deficiency. The other options are not related to lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lactose intolerance causes reduced absorption of lactose in the small intestine leading to increased water and gas production, resulting in abdominal symptoms like cramps, bloating, and flatulence. Among the options, only tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells are indicative of lactose intolerance. Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates is suggestive of celiac disease, periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages are seen in Whipple disease, and noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates are suggestive of sarcoidosis.
